What? That's a wild assumption.

0.author: ThePegasi
0.body:
OK, then my bad in turn. I thought your comment was consciously talking about trans women, clearly I was wrong. Sorry for misunderstanding and for making an incorrect accusation, that wasn't cool of me.

It was partly the trapped comment which made me think that too. Maybe it's just me, but it really doesn't take too long to realise someone's a cross dresser. Listening to OP's video with the sound on being an example, lol.

0.author: JasonIsBaad
0.body:
It's pretty cool to admit to a mistake/misunderstanding though! And yeah considering the literal definition of trapped I can get the misunderstanding, I didn't really mean it as literal as that. 

>Maybe it's just me, but it really doesn't take too long to realise someone's a cross dresser. Listening to OP's video with the sound on being an example, lol.

Yeah definitely, I kind of was joking about it, it's really not that bad.

0.author: ThePegasi
0.body: That's totally fair, I did leap off the deep end a bit and reading your comment back now I see where you were coming from. Thanks for the civil discussion even when I got overly accusative, and for the kind words. I make enough mistakes as it is, if anything admitting feels less silly than doubling down for pride's sake.

0.author: JasonIsBaad
0.body: No problem, it happens to the best of us. Have a great day mate!

1.author: smuglator
1.body: Yup, that's the one possible answer here in a shot up place. How observant of you, who haven't read anything and have no motive for your claim. Your supposed "only possible explanation" has no explanation to it at all.

1.author: Humbledshibe
1.body:
It's the only possible explanation.  I did read it, I doubt you did. It doesn't mention this at all. The motive is obvious : to make a striking picture. 

What do you think happened then?

1.author: smuglator
1.body: I think someone poked a round through a bullet hole. The journalist reporting on the site saw it. It's unusual to see that, so they took a picture of it and included in the article about the place. Not being an all knowing God, the journalist didn't know who or why they did it and simply, as is a journalist's job, reported the fact of what they found.

1.author: Humbledshibe
1.body:
Why would anyone put an unfired bullet into a hole unless to imply that that's where the hole came from. Even if it was to show scale, you'd think they would be holding it or take it from another angle. Or even mention it in the caption. 

You don't think it's more likely a journalist did this to try and make a "scary" picture? 

Excellent journalism "we found a thing, don't know how or why lol" they didn't even mention it as unusual. As though it was expected. You'd think they'd include something about it being unspent. 

Unless they thought it wasn't unusual because if it was a fired bullet, the context would be obvious.

1.author: smuglator
1.body: Welp, there you go choosing to jump to conclusions based on nothing but your own internal narrative. To answer your question: No, I don't think that because there's nothing in the article or image pointing to it. That's just what you want to see. And despite it not being there, you're still, somehow, convincing yourself that it is. So good bye.

1.author: Humbledshibe
1.body:
There's nothing in the article about it at all. That's the issue. We have to infer what it's about because of that. And it sure seems like someone who didn't know much about bullets.

Lmao

Bye!

2.author: igglesfangirl
2.body: And the wreck still would not have happened if the van had completed the pass and moved over as required. Let the police catch the bad drivers. Don't risk your life and other drivers'. As somebody who has driven 95S from Philly to Baltimore every summer weekend since 1993, I have seen many multi-vehicle accidents, sometimes on the same trip, all because left lane jerk sticks to 5 mph over the speed limit and won't budge no matter how long the line is behind him. Maryland was handing out more obstruction than speeding tickets for a while to make the point. It saves lives.

2.author: talltim007
2.body: I see someone slowing. I have no idea his motives and neither do you.

2.author: talltim007
2.body:
And when they speed ahead and kill a family of 4?

I think it is fine to get out of their way but I don't think you need to accommodate them either. 

I would have slowed down a bit more and merged. Behind the big rig. There is a reason for this. I had someone do this to me and I tried to complete my pass and the tailgater tried to pass me on the right while I was merging right. He passed on the right shoulder and nearly wiped me out when he merged back in because the shoulder ended abruptly. 

So I slow down to a speed that is safer if they get me and merge behind the vehicle I was overtaking because I can control that more.

The difference us the van is a minor annoyance and the car is a criminal. Any attempt at equivalence here is false.

6.author: ammonium_bot
6.body: You're really trying to change the meaning of "of" based on a mishearing? lol

6.author: tampora701
6.body:
I bet they told Rosa Parks the same thing. 

(before some idiot speaks up, no, this isnt me saying im courageous or revolutionary like her)

6.author: tampora701
6.body:
Im not trying to change anything. Meanings come from how words are used. Not the other way around.

It really feels like your trying to build a concrete structure with wet spaghetti and its just not going to work.  As much as you want it to be, language is not hard and fast.

On further deliberation,  I really feel sorry for you.  You so desperately need reliable structure in your life that you made a childish bot to tell everyone the way you want language to be, with no regards to what language actually is.

What a sad and small person you are.

6.author: ammonium_bot
6.body:
The vast majority of educated intelligent people accept and use "would have" as the correct expression. Therefore, based on your logic it is correct.

If we go the whole way with your logic, and accept whatever mishearings or misspellings people incorrectly use as correct usage, then there would be no such thing as grammar. Language teachers shouldn't bother to correct common mistakes that students make because now they're correct, right? At that rate we would never have mutually intelligible language.

Bruh get off your high horse lol I just made this bot for fun; it isn't that deep. It's not what I want language to be; it's the dictionary definition and what is accepted by the vast majority of English speakers.

8.author: Alive-East-1992
8.body:
I just dont think a child this young has hand-eye coordination or manual dexterity yet for this type of thing. Im all for having kids do chores and all, but the kid can barely walk. 
Have him put his toys in the toybox and do age appropriate things. 

Some friends of my were obsessed with having their 1 year old drink from a cup with no lid. Let her drink grape juice on a friend's white sofa. I'm sure you can imagine what happened. 
 i wouldn't even drink grape juice while sitting on a white sofa and im 43.

8.author: KoriBean2000
8.body: So I actually disagree a little bit with this one. First off, it’s not a huge deal if he spills it, the dogs are going to eat it regardless. And two, having him at least try to do these things early can not only build up those fine motor skills, but show him early on that he can/should be helpful when it comes to “chores”

8.author: Alive-East-1992
8.body:
Picking up toys will help with fine motor skills. Or just playing with toys.  

I guess my knee-jerk reaction is to just be a little annoyed with parents who try to make their kids grow up too fast. Then, kick them out the day they turn 18. That kind of parenting.  
They have the rest of their lives to be adults, probably at least 60 years or more of boring adulthood.  So let them be kids while they're kids. 
Obviously, they need to learn things and do chores, etc. But they don't need to accomplish it all by age 2.

8.author: KoriBean2000
8.body:
I absolutely hear you on that, it seems like so many parents will deep dive into early development, nutrition, etc. Just to be verbally abusive/dismissive in that child’s teens years (essentially ruining their efforts) 

But I do see value in what she’s doing tbh, I’ve seen a lot of studies on the specific benefits of “pouring activities” for younger kids. 

Trust me, watch a 3 year old over fill a cup by 1000% and pour juice on the floor awakens something within me lmao, but I think part of being a good parent is allowing for mistakes to happen.

9.author: Dragon420Wizard
9.body: I think that, regardless of it's intent, this word is objectively harmful. Nobody should use that word in my opinion.

9.author: DopeMOH
9.body: Objectively, it's definitely been used in a harmful way. It's probably also been used in objectively harmless ways. Words change meanings, especially depending on context and intent. If one person of color wants to use it as a term of endearment, despite its deeply rooted history in hate and systematic oppression, with another person of color, especially in an intimate circle or safe space, than I see no harm in it. I respect your principle, but I think it's just as valid if a person's principle is to reclaim it.

10.author: GodzeallA
10.body: Any one with 2 out of 3 of the main traits can score a 10. The 3 traits being money, size, and charm. But 10s usually look for all 3, because they can. Rarely do they score with someone who only has 1. So how many of those 3 does the average audience have? 0, 1, 2, or 3? And that'll get you close to the answer. But we aren't looking for the average. We are looking for the mode. Which means, if you were a person with 0 or 1 of those traits, you'd pick 1-3. If you were someone with 3 of those traits you'd pick 8-10. If you were someone with 2 of those traits you'd pick 5-7. What does this mean? 4 gets ZERO votes. That's what it means. Lol.

Tbh it's truth

We humans understand that it's a sign. 
The dog doesn't and thinks something is chasing him. They don't have any knowledge about technology and modern lifestyle which is disadvantage for them.

I don't care about your downvotes because I know it's true because I have general knowledge.

I will not say that dog have no IQ whatsoever.  
But lets think of it as you being chased by a killer, you are hearing alot of sounds around you and you think its the killer. ofc you will run as fast as you can. Same for dog, he thinks something is chasing him and when you are scared for you life. You IQ does nothing, so it means that the dog wasnt thinking and just running to save himself  


But the dog have lower IQ then human (I said lower which doesnt means they dont have any) and they dont know how technology works as i said above so for them that sign board and a car accident makes same sound so they might be running from it so they dont die  


I understand what you say but you misunderstood me. i only said lower which means lesser. You think that i said lower as in they are idiotic dumb

22.author: Wildlife_Jack
22.body:
Happy to help, but only if you continue to be mean ¯\\\_(ツ)_/¯ 

Where do you stand on dolphins in captivity? Let me guess, right on the poor dolphins.

22.author: Alsimni
22.body:
I was genuinely trying to figure out where the disconnect was, and then once it was found, you doubled down and refused to admit you'd misinterpreted the original post. Didn't realize it was mean to say what's happening.

Also dolphins are way too intelligent to be held in captivity without personal consideration. I wouldn't be surprised if there were even a way to "ask" them if they preferred the freedom of the wild or bring cared for by people on an individual basis. I like the choice of dolphins though, think they're a more interesting case than most.

22.author: Wildlife_Jack
22.body:
>I was genuinely trying to figure out where the disconnect was, and then once it was found, you doubled down and refused to admit you'd misinterpreted the original post. Didn't realize it was mean to say what's happening.

Don't agree. To me, this is akin to saying A-->B, given condition C. Except condition C is highly unlikely (an understatement). Hence my initial comment, which was just poking fun at the unlikelihood of the condition of "not terrified". IMO, domesticated animals are not comparable to wild animals in this scenario, their perception of human are vastly different, so it's a flawed inference. Now please do your thing.

>Also dolphins are way too intelligent to be held in captivity without personal consideration. I wouldn't be surprised if there were even a way to "ask" them if they preferred the freedom of the wild or bring cared for by people on an individual basis. I like the choice of dolphins though, think they're a more interesting case than most.

Well, I don't think most facilities that are heavily reliant on dolphins in captivities to bring them income are able to provide enough environmental and social enrichment to sustain a lifetime in captivity for such an intelligent animal. You absolute monster. /s

22.author: Alsimni
22.body:
Honestly, that's an understandable PoV that makes more sense than what I could tell. While the wording did describe that situation, it also fully agreed that the idea of the bird not being terrified was ludicrous, by bluntly staying that that wasn't the case, which was why I was so confused that you disagreed with it.

You're probably right about their resources for care, but I feel like something as intelligent as dolphins could have individuals that would still prefer captivity despite that, and possibly even demonstrate that if people took the effort to find a way to ask. It just feels like there's more to consider with a sapient animal compared to other wild animals.

27.author: Doombringer1968
27.body: I'm saying that no matter how strict gun laws are  that it doesn't matter if it's a US state or the federal government that makes these restrictions, people somehow always seem to find a way to obtain firearms. Wether that be through the purchase of stolen firearms or through newer methods such as 3D printing which has seen a massive rise in popularity.

27.author: Doombringer1968
27.body: Short answer Yes. Just look at some of the photos posted by the Chicago police department of all the crazy improvised weapons they produced.

33.author: Admirablelittlebitch
33.body: Dude, the matrix was written by trans women who I severely doubt were Christian and wanted to put Christian elements in their movie unless it was some random Christian character or something because it’s still a big thing in modern day society

33.author: Wild_Shape_8173
33.body:
Oh I also wanted to add to that comment, that sharpening up your biblical knowledge will bring more insightful context into these stories, like the Matrix.


 But I'm sorry but you're going to have to spare me the time tonight because this is a subject I could go on and on and on and on about but im trying to get this back and tricep day in and go to bed. Familiarize yourself with certain occult symbols. Especially Saturn worship and boy will you see them EEEEEEEEVERYWHERE in video games, music videos, and movies, company logos etc. Yes Satan uses his minions to *influence* the masses. 

Most of it goes right over your head, playing a video game, having the loading screen being Saturn with its spinning rings, music videos superbowl performances, standing inside of ritual circles dressed as Pharoahs and horned witches (Katy perry, Lady gaga). So many Celebrities posting images on social media taking baths in blood, covering one eye (no way you haven't seen the image compilations of celebrities covering one eye right?) Its not just silly random fun. At some point its not a random coincidence. Movies like Eyes wide shut are not works of fiction. There's a good starting point for you. 

I really do have to get back to my workout. Have a good night and thanks for being decently civil.

33.author: Wild_Shape_8173
33.body: Um...ya I'm well aware. These are certainly not Christians. Its just a reference. Its not a coincidence though. They didn't just fabricate the outlandish name of Nebuchadnezzar having no idea of its origin. Its completely intentional. So is the name Morpheus from Greek mythology. Believe me  I'm the last person you need to tell that Hollywood writers are not Christians lol.

33.author: Admirablelittlebitch
33.body: I just don’t think that their first thought had anything to do with religion

33.author: Wild_Shape_8173
33.body: Yup. Total coincidence that Morpheus is the God of dreaming in Greek mythology. Their first thought certainly wasn't Greek mythology with that but its Crazy how that worked out for them in the end. The survivors banished from earth and must all live in...Zion. just like the Jews in the Bible. Must have been totally random naming. I'd go play the lottery with those chances
